description:
Cercopithecus albogularis, commonly known as the Sykes' monkey or the white-throated guenon, is a species of Old World monkey found in East Africa. It is a medium-sized primate that belongs to the genus Cercopithecus, which is part of the family Cercopithecidae.

The Sykes' monkey has a distinctive appearance, with a black face, white throat, and a grayish-brown or olive-green coat. Its tail is long and serves as a counterbalance during locomotion. These monkeys are arboreal, spending most of their time in the trees, and are known for their agility and social behavior.

The species is found in a range of habitats, including tropical and subtropical forests, woodlands, and savannas. They are omnivorous, feeding on a variety of plant matter, fruits, insects, and small vertebrates.

Cercopithecus albogularis is considered a vulnerable species due to habitat loss and fragmentation, as well as hunting pressures in some areas. Conservation efforts are ongoing to protect this primate and its natural environment.
